headline: Sentiment Tracker: Social Network
summary: A computational analysis of the conversation on social networks.

headline: This Is One Silky Lipstick
summary: Sensai's The Lipstick multitasks with the same tireless energy as its wearer.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

Square feet of a billboard that the Minnesota Timberwolves are putting up on the side of their arena. The sign is directly in view of the right-field seats of the Minnesota Twins' ballpark, causing the park to be 'ambushed,' the team president says.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance for October 2, 2010.

headline: Men's File: Stripe-y Scarves
summary: Take that, gray flannel suit. A hit of graphic pattern perks up office wear like nobody's business.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Oct. 2, 2010

headline: Paraguay President Needs Emergency Treatment
summary: Paraguay's president, Fernando Lugo, will be rushed to a hospital in Sáo Paulo on Saturday afternoon for emergency treatment. He has been in a hospital in Paraguay since Thursday.

headline: Photos: College Football Saturday
summary: Photos from NCAA college football games across the country.

headline: Hunsicker Unlikely to Reunite With Mets
summary: Here's a name familiar to the Mets that they probably ought to cross of their list of prospective successors for general manager Omar Minaya: Gerry Hunsicker.

headline: U.S. to Issue European Travel Alert
summary: The U.S. State Department is moving to issue a travel alert Sunday warning American citizens to show vigilance in traveling to Europe, due to heightened concerns about an al Qaeda terrorist plot.

headline: Liberal Groups Stage D.C. Rally
summary: Union workers, civil-rights leaders and war protesters who have helped put Democrats in Congress and the White House tried to recapture the energy of recent elections Saturday on the National Mall, part of an effort to garner support before November's midterm elections.

headline: One Nation March
summary: Tapping into anger as the tea party movement has done, a coalition of progressive and civil rights groups marched Saturday on the Lincoln Memorial and pledged to support Democrats struggling to keep power on Capitol Hill.

headline: EU Offers to Give Up 2 IMF Seats
summary: The European Union's offer to give up two seats on the IMF's board is unlikely to gain approval, but it could be a template for a compromise.

headline: Bank of America Halts Foreclosures
summary: The Charlotte, N.C., lender is the latest bank to hold off on the process amid documentation problems across the country.

headline: Xinjiang Goldwind to Raise $916 Million in IPO
summary: Chinese wind-turbine maker Xinjiang Goldwind Science & Technology Co. priced its Hong Kong initial public offering in a deal set to raise around US$916 million.

headline: Obama Touts Clean Energy
summary: U.S. President Barack Obama on Saturday touted his clean energy agenda, predicting that his programs will create "hundreds of thousands" of new American jobs by 2012.

headline: Gandhi in Pictures
summary: India commemorates the birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi on Saturday. Snapshots from his life and legacy:

summary: Financial Briefing Book: Oct. 2-3

headline: Regulators Close Two Banks
summary: Regulators closed two small banks in Florida and Washington, raising the total number of bank failures in 2010 to 129.

headline: Weak Metals Market Poised for a Physical
summary: Imagine if you could turn all those wire hangers clogging up your closet into cash. Metals market analysts expect someone to do just that, albeit on a somewhat larger scale, by launching physically backed exchange-traded funds for industrial metals.

headline: In Brief: Gastronomy
summary: Rowan Jacobsen's "American Terroir" digs in to find out what can be savored "in our woods, waters, and fields." Aram Bakshian Jr. reviews.

headline: A Home on the Range
summary: A real-estate broker buys land in national forests and parks, then seeks to sell it to conservationists or the federal government. When no one met his price for a site in a rugged Colorado national park, he built himself a home.

headline: Chard and Tomato au Gratin
summary: The second of four easy-enough recipes by chef Daniel Rose of the restaurant Spring in Paris.

headline: Readers' Responses
summary: WSJ.com comments on articles from last week's Review.

headline: Tobias Harris: Japan's Precarious Budget Politics
summary: Prime Minister Naoto Kan needs a coalition of the willing.

headline: Sotheby's to Auction Allosaurus
summary: Sotheby's will hold its first natural-history auction in Paris, anchored by a 33-foot-long skeleton of an Allosaurus, the older, smaller cousin to the Tyrannosaurus Rex that roamed North America roughly 150 million years ago.

headline: A New Way to Cut a Mortgage
summary: Some homeowners who already have refinanced into low-interest-rate mortgages are using a little-known strategy to make their monthly payments even smaller.

headline: Ryders on the Storm
summary: After a seven-hour rain delay, the contest is on between Team USA and Team Europe, in a race to finish on Sunday.

headline: The Bond 'Bubble'
summary: The bond market is a bubble, and the little guy is blowing it. That has been a constant refrain on Wall Street, as retail investors poured billions into bond mutual funds. But they have had no choice if they wanted to earn income.

headline: Rooms With a Sound: Hotels Find a Groove
summary: The New York nightlife scene has been synonymous with hip hotel haunts for some time now. So, what differentiates one from the other? Well, the music, and each hotel has an in-house sound guru to prove it.

headline: Injured Kiwanuka To Sit Against Bears
summary: Versatile Giants defender won't play Sunday because of a bulging disc.

headline: Brazil's Surging Currency Figures in Election

summary: An international computer-crime ring that was broken up this week siphoned about $70 million in a hacking operation targeting bank accounts of small businesses, municipalities and churches.

summary: Now that the Ayodhya mosque has been settled, the BJP can adopt a more mature agenda.

headline: Leaky Rainsuits and Funny Bucket Hats
summary: Sartorial snafus, always part of the Ryder Cup; the British press has fun with Tiger names.

headline: Heather MacDonald: San Franciscans Try to Take Back Their Streets
summary: Even the liberal mayor is backing an initiative that would make public spaces safe again from the homeless industry and young thuggish vagrants.

headline: Charles R. Schwab: Enough With the Low Interest Rates!
summary: Fed policy punishes savers without making credit more readily available.

headline: An Unoffice-y Office
summary: The home work space of interior designer Todd Romano is antiques-friendly and Aeron-free. File under: chic.

summary: Business can't be held liable for overseas human rights abuses.

summary: ETFs were hit especially hard during the "flash crash" because trading volume dried up and prices became volatile, complicating the complex calculations necessary to value the securities.

headline: Maliki, Anti-U.S. Cleric Join Forces

summary: Ron Chernow's "Washington: A Life" gives us a George Washington whose true genius was for politics, not military strategy. Andrew Roberts reviews.

headline: Oil, Back as a Haven, Jumps Past $80
summary: Crude-oil futures finished the week at a eight-week high, as the commodity regains its status as a haven from a turbulent foreign-exchange market.

headline: Philip Roth Packs a Punch
summary: The author talks about the process behind his new book, 'Nemesis'

headline: In North Korea Photos, a General Trend
summary: A big winner of this week's North Korea leadership shuffle appears to be a little-known general whose several promotions have put him at the literal center of the country's political elite.

headline: India Seeks Positive Spin at Games

headline: Sec. Sebelius Knows Better About Insurance Regulation
summary: Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius may object to being called out on her department's Soviet style bullying tactics, but her op-ed ("Health Insurers Finally Get Some Oversight" Sept. 28) certainly reads like something out of Pravda.

summary: The forthcoming film "It's Kind of a Funny Story" transforms into a unique coming-of-age story grounded in modern-day Brooklyn reality and gilded with flights of magic realism.

summary: Corrections and amplifications for Oct. 1, 2010.

headline: The Waltz That Defines Vienna
summary: To this day, Strauss's magnificent "Blue Danube" waltz is the veritable anthem of Vienna.

headline: Olmec 'Baby' Visits an L.A. Museum
summary: The Olmec people who once ruled southern Mexico are best known for 20-ton stone sculptures of their kings scowling under chunky helmets. But a new exhibit at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, "Olmec: Colossal Masterworks of Ancient Mexico," proves the Olmecs also excelled on a smaller scale.

headline: Fuel-Efficiency Targets Head Higher
summary: Passenger cars would have to obtain an average of up to 62 miles a gallon by 2025 under an initiative by the Obama administration to control greenhouse-gas emissions

summary: Carl Rollyson on how biographers have approached the George Washington, from focusing on a single period of his life to producing multivolume attempts to encompass an extraordinary story.

summary: Tips and recommendations for your next long weekend trip, Thanksgiving travel, and organizing tiny closets.

headline: Photo Sessions

summary: The $3.2 billion merger of United Airlines parent UAL and Continental closed Friday, bringing the two big carriers together in a company called United Continental Holdings.

summary: The ARC Angel Fund, a fledgling circle of 33 private investors (aka angels), pooled their money this summer to form what amounts to a mini venture-capital fund for local software, media, tech and wireless startups.

headline: Ecuador's Top Cop Quits After President Held
summary: Ecuador's police chief quit and Army troops patrolled the presidential palace Friday, as questions emerged over whether President Rafael Correa had overdramatized events surrounding what he characterized as a coup the previous day.

headline: School Reform Rainmakers
summary: John Walton had the right idea for education donors.

summary: These smart shoes look great with men's-style pants, leggings and even skirts and dresses.

headline: Grief, Outrage at Rutgers
summary: On a rainy, overcast day, Rutgers University students dropped flowers, photos and notes at a memorial shrine set up to honor a freshman who leaped off the George Washington Bridge to his death.

headline: Lions' Road Woes Reach Rarefied Air

headline: Me, Myself (My Thumb, My Arm) and My Camera
summary: How to take digital pictures of yourself that look half-decent.

headline: Hear It, Feel It
summary: In "The Music Instinct" Philip Ball explores the how we hear music and what it says to us. Is emotion inherently part of music, or do we simply impose that meaning on it? Eric Felten reviews.

summary: At midnight on the first of the month, a scene unfolds at many Wal-Mart sites that underscores the deep financial strains that many low-income American consumers still face.

headline: This Week
summary: What happened to your money this week.

summary: Events in Washington, Detroit, San Francisco and New York.

headline: Home Slump? Not on City Tax Bill
summary: Through all the turmoil that erased billions of dollars from the value of U.S. homes, owners in New York City are seeing their property tax continue to rise without skipping a beat.

headline: Fund Managers Dive Into Stocks
summary: With bond yields near historic lows, some managers of global-allocation mutual funds say stocks are starting to look like better alternatives.

headline: A Gangster Goes to War

section: The Grand Fanalysis: Jets vs. Giants
headline: Our Jets and Giants Fan Poll
summary: An exclusive survey reveals the traits of area football fans. If the Jets have been hogging the headlines, it's not because they have a larger fan base.

headline: Why Some Islanders Build Better Crab Traps
summary: Matt Ridley's Mind & Matter column looks at what a South Pacific study on remote and connected islanders can tell us about modern, Internet-dominated society.

headline: Brass Beds and Broomsticks
summary: Why did we begin using brass beds? To dispel climbing vermin. What's inside old pillows? Living and dead mites. Bill Bryson's "At Home: A Short History of Private Life" brims with diverting anecdotes. Meghan Cox Gurdon reviews.

headline: New H-P CEO Gets Rich Pay Package
summary: In naming Leo Apotheker its new CEO, H-P picked a leader with a heavy sales focus and a reputation for making tough decisions. He also received an initial pay package that could be worth more than $50 million.

headline: CFTC Unveils Derivatives Proposal
summary: U.S. regulators unveiled a series of proposed governance rules for derivatives clearinghouses and trading platforms that are designed to protect the market.

summary: Rowan Jacobsen's "American Terroir" digs in to find out what can be savored "in our woods, waters, and fields." Aram Bakshian Jr. reviews.

summary: China issued a travel warning for Japan, reflecting continued strains between the two neighbors despite efforts to ratchet down tensions.

headline: The Bosom is Back

headline: 'Things Could Get Pretty Messy'
summary: The man who would be the next House majority leader talks about the GOP agenda and working with Obama.

headline: Sarkozy Looks to Boost Image Via China
summary: France's President Nicolas Sarkozy has an ambitious plan for his Group-of-20 presidency: Get China to talk about exchange rates.

headline: President Bush Really Did Leave a Fiscal Mess Behind
summary: Steve Moore's "The Pelosi-Reid Deficits" (op-ed, Sept. 29) on the deficit is highly misleading. The $4.09 trillion projected deficit he cites assumes that all of the tax cuts passed under President George W. Bush will expire.

headline: Yorkville: Growing Above and Below Ground
summary: In recent years, more uber-luxurious high-rises have opened in Yorkville, further altering the neighborhood's skyline and bringing more buyers seeking some slight relief from higher-priced housing to Yorkville's west.

headline: Goldman Opens Wallet Early
summary: The Wall Street bank took the unusual step of granting midyear bonuses to about 100 partners in London, in a move to retain top talent.

headline: Ryan Sees Defense Improving
summary: If Mr. Ryan is concerned—even mildly concerned—about the unit's play as the Jets prepare to visit the Buffalo Bills on Sunday, nobody can tell. Say this much for the team's second-year coach: He is a confident man.

headline: Rejection Hertz
summary: Hertz played chicken with Dollar Thrifty shareholders and got burned. Now, it's Avis Budget's turn to step up.

headline: Mystery Chronicle
summary: Tom Nolan reviews a trio of new mysteries: Michael Connelly's "The Reversal," with detective Harry Bosch and defense attorney Mickey Haller teaming up again; Tom Franklin's "Crooked Letter, Crooked Letter," about decades-apart disappearances of young women in the South; and Robert B. Parker's posthumously published "Painted Ladies," with the Boston private detective Spenser back in action.

headline: Week in Ideas
summary: On the benefits of cursing doctors, why men don't apologize and the dangers of cutting foreign aid.

headline: Tropical Rains Soak, Stall Area
summary: Remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole slammed the New York region with rain and high wind Friday, delaying flights, flooding roads and causing thousands of households to lose power.

summary: The eagerly awaited report on the causes of the May 6 "flash crash" portrayed a market so fragmented and fragile that a single large trade could send stocks into a sudden spiral.

headline: Fashionable Baggage Tags
summary: The unsung hero of the baggage carousel just got a little snappier.

headline: Will Apotheker's Potion Boost H-P?
summary: Hewlett-Packard is going on the offensive with its unexpected choice to lead the company. The appointment could prove shrewd, though it raises plenty of questions.

headline: Five Best in International Crime Fiction
summary: Geoffrey O'Brien, the editor in chief of the Library of America, on top crime tales.

headline: Retailers Tread Fine Line in Testing Pricing
summary: Companies that sell consumer mainstays from beer to dresses, from steaks to tires, are rolling out price increases in a collective test of America's economic strength.

headline: Latest Tax Bill Places Big Bite on City Elite
summary: Here are some of the biggest tax increases for owners of condominiums and townhouses.

headline: Rajasthan's New Crown Jewel Hotels
summary: India's five-star hotel boom hits the princely state of Rajasthan, where a trio of chic properties open this fall.

headline: What Master Does AARP Serve?
summary: John Rother of AARP must be crazy if he thinks Medicare will be better under ObamaCare (Letters, Sept. 27).

headline: As Sales Indicator, Weathervanes Spin Around
summary: Weathervanes aren't just a way to discern the weather—they also serve as a barometer for the entire Americana market.

headline: Bank Aid Rankles Irish Voters
summary: Ireland's failure to stem the costs of its banking rescue is stoking citizens' ire at the bankers and politicians they hold responsible for the country's property bust, and fueling debate about how the government should pay its debts.

headline: Impalement Artist Takes Stab at 'Wheel of Death'
summary: A former knife-throwing world champion—and current holder of 16 world records-—is taking a stab at one of the most dangerous feats in knife throwing: The Veiled Wheel of Death.

headline: In Brief: Literary Fright
summary: Harry Bruce's "Page Fright" explores, as the subtitle has it, "The Foibles and Fetishes of Famous Writers." Dave Shiflett reviews.

headline: Faith-Based vs. Government-Based
summary: Any lingering doubts about the corrupting influence of government should be dispelled by Jim Towey's op-ed "Pastors For ObamaCare?" (Sept. 25).

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Historian Victor Davis Hanson writes that the American university is the most politically intolerant and monolithic institution in the country.

headline: Midnight Shoppers
summary: At midnight on the first of the month, Wal-Mart parking lots suddenly bustle with life and customers cram shopping carts full of milk, diapers, infant formula and other basic staples -- a sad trend that underscores the deep financial strain still being felt by the low-end consumer.

headline: Emanuel Makes Departure Official
summary: President Obama announced the departure of Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel and named adviser Pete Rouse as his interim successor.

headline: Making Money Off The Rich
summary: Stocks that could rise when the wealthy open their pocketbooks.

headline: The ETF Rush of 2010:Gold Funds Gain Favor
summary: Historically high gold prices are driving investors into exchange-traded funds and mining-company stock mutual funds at a time when many investors are shedding their stakes in stock funds.

headline: What the Unitarians Don't Know (and Sam Harris Doesn't)
summary: In "The Moral Landscape" Sam Harris attempts to explain the scientific basis of human values. Marilynne Robinson reviews.

headline: Hiring Data Tell Different Stories
summary: Government estimates on employment show greater hiring growth than a closely watched private estimate. The discrepancy comes down to methodology, and not everyone agrees on which number is more reliable.

headline: Bridging a Borough's Food Gap
summary: Manhattan is the foodie's paradise, serving up treats from the interiors of China to the delicacies of former Yugoslavian countries. Now, a new fare is making its way in, its only journey across a bridge: food from Brooklyn.

headline: Americans Sour on Free Trade
summary: The American public, already skeptical of free trade, is becoming increasingly hostile to it. The ire has clouded prospects for approval of pending free-trade pacts, and prompted concern among U.S. businesses reliant on the rest of the world for growth.

headline: New Mouse, Double iPod Dock
summary: A look at some of the latest in tech.

headline: Fred Siegel: The Broadway-Buffalo Divide
summary: Gothamites who disparage Carl Paladino would do well to understand why other New Yorkers voted for him.

headline: Great Scott! The Guy Could Write
summary: In this Word Craft column, biographer Blake Bailey appreciates Fitzgerald's "The Great Gatsby."

headline: Before the End, Kabuki Theater
summary: Mr. Manuel is in the final year of his contract and has just overseen another bus wreck of a season. Both he and the media members questioning him know he's unlikely to return.

headline: Amy Bonnaffons: It's Not You, It's Your Bedbugs
summary: WebMD might be an enabler of delusion, but I can't stop itching.

headline: Cuomo Lines Up Business Backers
summary: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Andrew Cuomo and his closest friends are aggressively seeking to corral public support from an array of elite figures in the city's real estate and investment worlds.

headline: Retreats Surrender to Wi-Fi
summary: Steven Kurutz on how the incursion of Internet connectivity has altered life  in artists' getaways like Yaddo and the MacDowell Colony.

headline: Ukraine Court Ruling Empowers Leader
summary: A top Ukrainian court ruled that constitutional changes passed in 2004 were unlawful, fuelling fears of increasingly authoritarian rule.

headline: Dying Languages
summary: Linguists estimate that one of the world's 7,000 languages dies every 14 days. A look at some endangered tongues.

headline: U.S. Apologizes for Syphilis Study
summary: The U.S. apologized to Guatemala for a study 60 years ago in which American scientists deliberately infected prisoners in that country with syphilis.

headline: Harrisburg Asks State for Relief
summary: Harrisburg, Pa., warning that it "stands on the precipice of a full-blown financial crisis," asked for state help in repairing its finances.

headline: New Data Highlight Weak Recovery
summary: With the recovery largely stuck in neutral, the president of the Fed Reserve Bank of New York signaled the Fed was preparing actions aimed at boosting growth.

headline: How Risky Are Those Low-Risk Funds?
summary: In an effort to manage risk, some fund firms are reinventing the "balanced" funds that form the core of many investors' portfolios. They might be creating new risks of their own.

headline: Guess Who's Coming to Dinner? Beer
summary: Thanks to a new school of "beer sommeliers," brews are spilling out of the gastropub and into the world of fine dining.

headline: Facebook Splits Stock 5-for-1
summary: Facebook announced a 5-for-1 stock split, a move the privately held company said would allow it to issue more shares to employees—though the value of such awards wouldn't change.

headline: Program Chief at MTV Is Leaving
summary: Tony DiSanto, who helped engineer a renaissance at MTV as its head of original programming, is leaving the network.

headline: The Federal Judge With Terror on Her Docket
summary: When failed Times Square bomber Faisal Shahzad is sentenced Tuesday, he will be up against a jurist whose previous cases have included charges against Martha Stewart, a boxing dispute, and a challenge to the legality of "ladies night" promotions at nightclubs.

headline: Tobacco Sales Face Constraints
summary: The federal government ruled that retailers that sell cartons produced by rolling machines in their stores must obtain manufacturing permits and pay applicable taxes.

headline: Building Blocks of a Book
summary: Philip Roth on how he writes

headline: CIA Escalates Campaign in Pakistan
summary: The U.S. military is secretly diverting aerial drones and weaponry from the Afghan battlefront to significantly expand the CIA's campaign against militants in their Pakistani havens.

headline: Higher Education at a Lower Cost
summary: Introduced in 1996, 529 college-savings plans have had a mixed record of success. Now they're causing grandparents some distress too.

headline: Taking Senses to the Extreme
summary: Lance Esplund reviews Eve Sussman and the Rufus Corporation's "The Rape of the Sabine Women," Pipilotti Rist and the Morris Graves retrospective.

headline: Twenty Years, One Germany
summary: On Sunday, Germans will mark the 20-year anniversary of the reunification of East Germany and West Germany.

headline: Quirky Lopez Is a Cornerstone for Nets
summary: Labeled a centerpiece of the franchise by coach Avery Johnson, the center won't compare himself to the NBA's elite big men.
